prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The main goal is to resolve the gas in the disk around four transitional disks. We request a spatial resolution of 0.18 arcsecond in Band 6 with the most extended antenna configuration. The extention of the source is less than 2 arcsec, which is within the maximum recoverable scale of the most extended antenna configuration.
In order to conduct uniform observations, we request same exposure time in our four targets. The exposure time was estimated from the peak flux of PDS 70 which has a less massive disks than others (see table 1). Thus, this estimate would result in minimum SN ratio.
According to our SMA observations of PDS70, the peak flux of 12CO(2-1) was 1 Jy/beam*km/s with a beam size of 1.0 x 0.5 arcsec^2 (fig.2-a3). Assuming homogeneous flux with a beam in SMA observations of PDS70, the peak flux in our observations could be 1 Jy/beam*km/s x ((0.18 x 0.18) / (1.0 x 0.5)) = 0.065 Jy/beam*km/s. This estimation would be conservative. When we request a sensitively of 0.65 mJy/beam, the SN ratio would achieve to be 100 and estimated-total-observational-time is 0.5 hours.
We also set 13CO, and C18O in order to estimate the amount of gas in our targets.

In order to conduct uniform observations, we request same exposure time and same observational setting in our four targets. The exposure time was estimated from the peak flux of PDS 70 which has a less massive disks than others (see table 1). Thus, this estimate would result in minimum SN ratio.

In order to conduct uniform observations, we request same exposure time and same observational setting in our four targets. The exposure time was estimated from the peak flux of PDS 70 which has a less massive disks than others (see table 1). Thus, this estimate would result in minimum SN ratio.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to investigate the final stage of protoplanetary disk evolution with ALMA. Our tagets (PDS~70, RX~J1604.3$-$2130, IRAS~04125$+$2902, and Sz~91) are weak-line T Tauri stars (WTTS) that have so-called {\it transitional disks}. The large cavities ($r>$20 ~AU) in the central disk-region around these four objects have been imaged at both (sub-)mm and near-infrared (NIR) wavelengths, and this imagery suggests the large-mm-size and small-sub-$\mu$m-size dust grains are dissipated inside the cavity. Among the many transitional disks that have been discovered around classical T Tauri stars (CTTS), these four WTTS systems are likely to be more evolved and close to the epoch of their final stage of disk evolution. We propose to use Band~6 observations at a maximum spatial resolution of 0.$''$18 to measure the amount of gas inside the cavity, in order to obtain observational evidence of gas-decreasing in transitional disks around WTTS.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
